Award.AwardTitle: Gamma Ray and Neutrino Observations of GRBs and choked GRBs
Award.AbstractNarration:
Gamma Ray Bursts (GRBs) are among the most powerful events in the Universe. With this award the Georgia Tech group will use HAWC and IceCube data to study high-energy gamma ray and neutrino emission from GRBs. The HAWC observatory, currently under construction in Mexico, will be at an order of magnitude more sensitive to GRB emission than previous ground-based instruments. The group will play an important role in the design and construction of HAWC, particularly in the electronics and software related to the study of GRBs. The HAWC data may teach us about the highest energy particles accelerated by GRBs and may reveal details about the relativistic jets that power a GRB. IceCube is a high-energy neutrino telescope in operation at the South Pole. The group will use data collected by DeepCore, a low energy extension of IceCube, to search for transient bursts of neutrinos. To enhance DeepCore's sensitivity they will collect data with a new, looser vetoing technique. They will study the connection between core collapse supernovae (SNe) and GRBs and the hypothesis that many core collapse SNe have hidden or choked jets. The discovery of neutrinos in coincidence with core collapse SNe would prove that they and GRBs are part of continuous class of astrophysical objects.

Broader Impact: The Georgia Tech group will report HAWC observations promptly to enable multi-messenger follow up with neutrinos (notably IceCube/DeepCore), gravitational waves, X-rays, etc., thus extending the scientific range of the experiments. In collaboration with CEISMC at Georgia Tech the PI and members of his group will continue their program of lectures and hands on demonstrations in the areas of particle and nuclear physics and astrophysics. Demonstrations include devices such as a cloud chamber and a Geiger counter. The high schools targeted have a large Hispanic population, for which the PI, born in Latin America, has a natural connection.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit

There were two main objectives to this proposal: 1) Study gamma-ray bursts (GRBs), choked GRBs and other short transients with the IceCube neutrino telescope.2) Participate in the construction and operation of the HAWC gamma ray observatory.

GRBs are very powerful explosions that, briefly, can outshine the rest of the universe. GRBs are expected to be sources of very-high-energy neutrinos and gamma rays. Choked GRBs are hypothesized to be similar to GRBs, but without an electromagnetic signal associated with it. The methods used in this proposal are applicable to any type of short (less than 1 day) astonomical transient. Neutrinos can be studied with IceCube and gamma rays with HAWC. 

In IceCube two major pieces of work were conducted supported by this grant: Student James Casey performed a correlation study between known GRBs and neutrinos of astrophysical (but unknown origin) discovered by IceCube. He found no correlation and place a limit of 12% (~45%) as the fraction of the astrophysical neutrinos detected by IceCube that can come from GRBs within 20 hours (15 days) of each GRBs. This result has been presented at the International Cosmic Ray Conference of 2013. Casey obtained a PhD in May 2015. Student Jacob Daughhetee used 30-300 GeV neutrino data from IceCube to search for transients everywhere in the northern sky. This is a previousy under-studied energy range. Daughhetee found no evidence for transients and place a limit on the local universe rate of choked GRBs. This work has been submitted to the astrophysical Journal. Daugheetee received a PhD in May 2015. 

Construction of HAWC is now finished (March 2015). Georgia Tech succesful finished construction of scalers and the high voltage system. Scalers monitor the health of the main detection units of HAWC (1200 photomultipliers). Scalers are working with >99% up time and no significant failures. The High Voltage system has had a similar excellent performance. 

Taboada and Gilmore (UC Santa Cruz) calculated the rate at which GRBs can be detected by HAWC, and found that it is ~1.6 GRB/year or lower, depending on the astrophysics of GRBs. This work was published in NIM A. Postdoc Dirk Lennarz performed a study of GRB 130427A, the brightest GRB in 30 years with a partially built HAWC and found no gamma ray emission - However, the location on the sky of this GRB was very unfavorable for this burst. A limit on the ~100 GeV emission was placed. This work has been published in the Astrophysical Journal. Lennarz also studied 18 GRBs reported by Swift with a partially built fHAWC and found no evidence for gamma ray emission. This work was reported at the International Cosmic Ray Conference of 2015.  

Taboada has studied IceCube astrophysical neutrino locations reported by IceCube with HAWC - as in some cases simultanous emission is expected. For the highest energy neutrino ever reported by IceCube (multi-PeV), no evidence for emission was found.

Broader impacts

Data produced by Daughhetee is very innovative, as the 30-300 GeV energy range is mostly unstudied. This data set is being used by at least 4 other graduate students in IceCube.

HAWC study of GRB 130427A was promptly reported by a GCN circular, the community standard for reporting results of GRB observations. GCN circulars allow for follow up observations and enhance the science output of many facilities.

The HAWC follow up of IceCube's highest energy event was reported as an astronomer's telegram (ATEL). ATEL are community standard for astronomical information. ATELs enhance the science output of many facilities.
